DOC.HEAD: Condemnation of Romanian Repression Grows
Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to add Britain to list asking for Security Council meeting, add quote; picks up 5th `Demonstrations against'
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: European governments issued new condemnations Thursday of the bloody repression in Romania and President Francois Mitterrand of France said the Stalinist regime's ``days are numbered.'' China said the events in Romania were an internal affair. In Beijing, the China-Romania Friendship Association opened a laudatory photographic exhibit called ``Romania in Socialist Construction.'' West Germany, Austria, Britain and Hungary requested an urgent meeting of the U.N. Security Council. Javier Perez de Cuellar, the U.N. secretary-general, expressed ``profound anxiety'' about developments in Romania. ``It is essential that this situation be handled with scrupulous respect for the universal Declaration of Human Rights and in accordance with the U.N. Charter,'' Perez de Cuellar said. Britain urged ``all nations'' to condemn ``this behavior, which is an affront to all internationally accepted norms.'' Demonstrations against President Nicolae Ceausescu's government began last weekend in Timisoara, a city in western Romania, and have spread to other parts of the country, including Bucharest. Estimates by witnesses of the number of people killed in Timisoara range from hundreds to 4,000. Reports from Bucharest said security forces fired into crowds of protesters in the capital Thursday, but no precise casualty reports were available. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the U.S. Embassy in Buchrest reported that 13 young people were killed by automatic weapons fire from government security forces during the demonstration. He said other fatalities may have occurred as well. Romania's conduct has isolated it from Warsaw Pact allies, where the trend is toward democracy and economic reform. Thousands of people chanting anti-Ceausescu slogans and waving banners for freedom gathered outside Romanian embassies in Prague, Budapest and Belgrade, the capitals of Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Yugoslavia. Demonstrators burned an effigy of Ceauesescu outside the Romanian Embassy in Vienna, Austria. In Paris, Federico Mayor, the head of the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, summoned Romanian representative Petre Gigea and reminded him Romania had promised to uphold human dignity before it was allowed to join UNESCO. At the end of the current round of the East-West conventional arms talks in Vienna, a diplomat expressed concern that the trouble in Romania could jeopardize negotiations on reducing military forces in Europe. ``It's feared that Hungary and Romania will no longer sit on the same side of the negotiation table,'' the diplomat said privately. Official Soviet reaction was cautious, but coverage of Romania by the state news agency Tass gave vivid accounts of violence against demonstrators. ``If we do receive information on victims among people we, of course, will be extremely sorry about them,'' said Vadim Perfiliev, a spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry. ``We should emphasize that we do have opinions on what is happening, but ... I cannot go into comments without having all-inclusive information and orders in that regard.'' On a visit to East Berlin, Mitterrand was more direct. ``It is a regime of personal, family power that has no honest reason to remain,'' he said. ``I think that the days of this regime, in a Europe in full movement, are numbered.'' He ruled out foreign intervention amd said: ``The response has to come from Romania.'' In Bonn, Helmut Kohl's chief spokesman, Hans Klein, said the chancellor was ``deeply shocked by the brutal repression of the justified and peaceful protests. He strongly condemns the massive use of weapons and the reprehensible attempts by the Romanian leadership to suppress the efforts for freedom and democracy.'' Klein said Kohl ``appeals to those responsible at all levels in Romania to halt repression by the military and security police, and to open a dialogue on the justified demands of people.'' In London, the Foreign Office said withdrawing their ambassadors from Romania was one of several options being considered by the 12 European Community members. Italy announced it had recalled its ambassador, Luigi Amaduzzi, for consultations. East Germany condemned the ``brutal action of the Romanian state power against peaceful citizens demonstrating to assert their elementary human rights.'' It urged the Romanian government stop the violence and recalled Ambassador Herbert Plaschke for consultations. Czechoslovakia summoned a senior Romanian diplomat to receive a protest from the Foreign Ministry in Prague. Government and other protests continued in Hungary, which has tense relations with Ceausescu's regime because of alleged harassment of the 1.7 million ethnic Hungarians in Romania. ``There exists or has developed in Romania a serious political movement,'' said Foreign Minister Gyula Horn. ``It is an anti-Ceausescu movement. There is no accurate information on its strength, or the extent to which it has spread.'' Greece condemned the suppression and the Athens Academy of Sciences canceled the membership awarded in 1976 to Ceausescu's wife, Elena, the second most powerful person in Romania.
